snippet.textDisplay: Thing was, I didn't realize this until later, but the weird video in the background of the menu is actually a close-up of the nuclei of a Metroid.
snippet.textOriginal: Thing was, I didn't realize this until later, but the weird video in the background of the menu is actually a close-up of the nuclei of a Metroid.

snippet.textDisplay: Greatest. Menu. Music. Ever. Druids? Flippin druids humming in the background during the menu? Yeah, this is about to be epic! Menu music is not supposed to sound this amazing, first time I heard this, goosebumps everywhere! Retro Studios hit the nail on the head with this theme that set the pace and the tone for every piece of music in Metroid Prime that followed. Perfect.
snippet.textOriginal: Greatest. Menu. Music. Ever. Druids? Flippin druids humming in the background during the menu? Yeah, this is about to be epic! Menu music is not supposed to sound this amazing, first time I heard this, goosebumps everywhere! Retro Studios hit the nail on the head with this theme that set the pace and the tone for every piece of music in Metroid Prime that followed. Perfect.

snippet.textDisplay: The problem with Other M isn't that Nintendo is slipping, so much as it's that Nintendo never understood how Retro used newer, more innovative exploration elements to create a more atmospheric, interesting, rewarding, exploration-leading-to-discovery, grandiose title. I wouldn't blame corporate greed so much as Yoshio Sakamoto's lack of understanding towards his own series. (Not that corporate greed isn't prevelant. See also Mass Effect 3 and any Capcom release after RE4's GCN release)
snippet.textOriginal: The problem with Other M isn't that Nintendo is slipping, so much as it's that Nintendo never understood how Retro used newer, more innovative exploration elements to create a more atmospheric, interesting, rewarding, exploration-leading-to-discovery, grandiose title. I wouldn't blame corporate greed so much as Yoshio Sakamoto's lack of understanding towards his own series. (Not that corporate greed isn't prevelant. See also Mass Effect 3 and any Capcom release after RE4's GCN release)

snippet.textDisplay: Sadly corporate greed such as EA and Activision set in to monetize the gaming industry making it stagnate. Nintendo is slipping, Other M has no soundtrack and was mediocre overall, what a black sheep of the Metroid franchise.

snippet.textDisplay: Really? Given the fantastic story-telling in Metroid Prime, I feel Retro can do more with a 3D game than any company could do with a 2D game.  Sure, the whole "throwback" thing is nice, but Metroid has evolved far beyond that, and as a whole, would only be downgraded by such.
snippet.textOriginal: Really? Given the fantastic story-telling in Metroid Prime, I feel Retro can do more with a 3D game than any company could do with a 2D game.  Sure, the whole "throwback" thing is nice, but Metroid has evolved far beyond that, and as a whole, would only be downgraded by such.

snippet.textDisplay: I'd be less interested in a Retro developed fourth Metroid Prime, and more interested in a Retro developed 2D Metroid. Donkey Kong Country Returns showed that they can make magnificent level designs in a 2D game. Heck, it's been nearly a decade since the last 2D Metroid game, not counting Zero Mission (a remake).
snippet.textOriginal: I'd be less interested in a Retro developed fourth Metroid Prime, and more interested in a Retro developed 2D Metroid. Donkey Kong Country Returns showed that they can make magnificent level designs in a 2D game. Heck, it's been nearly a decade since the last 2D Metroid game, not counting Zero Mission (a remake).

snippet.textDisplay: I don't remember the last time I uploaded two tracks from the same game so closely together, but Metroid Prime launched exactly 10 years ago so I couldn't pass that up. It makes me realise how video games have been evolving very slowly, especially when you compare the 1992-2002 jump to the 2002-2012 one. I'd be willing to spend quite the sum for a Metroid Prime 4 on the Wii U made by Retro.
snippet.textOriginal: I don't remember the last time I uploaded two tracks from the same game so closely together, but Metroid Prime launched exactly 10 years ago so I couldn't pass that up. It makes me realise how video games have been evolving very slowly, especially when you compare the 1992-2002 jump to the 2002-2012 one. I'd be willing to spend quite the sum for a Metroid Prime 4 on the Wii U made by Retro.
